review_blob: This is one of the most bland German beers Ive ever tasted. However, it makes a decent chaser.

500ml bottle. Have only recently tried beer from this brewery and am glad I have. This has to rank right up there with Celebrator. Only I detected a hint of cocoa, which was nice. This is a fine doppelbock which Ill be buying again.

Im new to wheat beers and find them interestingly different. Dont know why wheat would yield flavors of banana and cloves, but it does--big time. Unfiltered cloudiness also seems to be a common factor. I cant really compare this beer to many others because I havent tried many others. Am working to change that. For now, it is just an interesting diversion.
Using this to chase Pappy Van Winkle shots. Let it warm up to near room temp first. Coffee, chocolate, something else, but I cant put my finger on it. Very, very nice.
beer_name: Big Sky Ivan The Terrible Imperial Stout

review_blob:
I have become a fan of Full Sail. Especially since my local store sells their six packs for $4.99!
This particular IPA is heavier on the malt than most and not as heavy on the hops. I like it! The label emphasizes the "tastiness". I tend to agree. This is a very tasty beer.

Bomber bottled exactly one year ago today. Served at about 50 degrees in a pint glass. Pours a clear brandy hue with moderate carbonation. Fine thick head with moderate lacing. Delicious maltiness and slight hop presence. Alcohol is well hidden. This is the best American doppelbock I have tried and find it better than some German ones.
I thought I was buying German beer. Turns out I was wrong. This swill is made in St. Louis, MO. Shame on Becks for the deception. I will never buy Becks again.

First Ive tried from this brewery. Not particularly impressed. Pours a burgundy color with a good but short lived head. Aroma is off. Hate to say it but it reminds me of Steel Reserve (yes, Ive poured that swill down my gizzard). Palate is somewhat better, but the metal is still there. Hard to find any redeeming features about this one. Maybe Ill try another one of theirs.
This is an underrated beer that I often find on special for 6 bucks a sixer.  It has a good hop/malt balance and is easy on the tongue.  It makes a good chaser for the bourbons I like.

2012.  This barleywine is delicious.  Reminds me of a long gone beer called Tree Spirit Stout by the Santa Fe Brewery, which I miss.  Will be picking up some more of these bombers when I can afford them!

22 ounce bomber for $7.49 at North Park in Westminster.  "Seven Seas" title is gone, but rest of label looks the same.  The ingredients and alcohol level match, so I will assume this is the same beer.  

I popped the cap with the bottle at about 50 degrees.  It poured a translucent honey hue with a dense white head which was slow to dissipate.  The nose was enticing.  Taste revealed one of the best balanced IPAs I have tried.  Chewy on the palate and with a lingering bitter finish.  The 9 percent alcohol is well hidden.  This beer is excellent!
beer_name: Dry Dock Seven Seas Double IPA

review_blob: Found this on sale for 6 bucks a sixer!  Pours a hazy pale orange with a long lasting fluffy white head.  Excellent lacing and carbonation.  Tastes like any number of fine IPAs on the market.  I really like this beer.
This tastes to me like a IPA light.  IPAs are not meant to be light.  Thus, the low score.  Not a  bad beer, but not a good IPA.

4 pack bottles from Total in Westminster.  Pours a slightly hazy amber with a fluffy, fairly long lasting head.  Good malt presence which balances the abundant hops.  First brew Ive tried from this brewery.  Very nice beer!
OK, its not exactly a world class beer, but it does a pretty good job of removing tar from the chrome on my car.
beer_name: Camo Silver Ice High Gravity Lager

review_blob: 12 ounce bottle from a 4-pack.  Nice marketing on this one; the label really stood out.  This is a great imperial/double IPA!  Reminded me of Great Divide Hercules.  Over the top amounts of hops and malt fermented to a high ABV.  Just my style.  Sierra Nevada just keeps putting out better and better beers.  I hope this one will not be as seasonal as Bigfoot.
This is yet another nice canned beer from a Colorado brewery.  Well balanced and tasty.  And on sale for $7.99 a sixer.  I think Ill stick a case in my saddlebags and head for the hills.
beer_name: Steamworks 3rd Eye Enlightened Pale Ale (Third Eye)

review_blob: 12 oz. can.  Pours a hazy dark orange with above average carbonation.  Thick white head and nice lacing.  Nice malt/hops balance.  This one stands out among a lot of IPAs.

Bt the time I got this 4 pack of 12 ouncers home, they were at a great temperature to drink (50ish).  It poured a thick opaque with big head which settled slowly.  The first thing to jump out was the cocoa, then the hops; an interesting one-two punch that was very enjoyable.  The alcohol was well hidden.  I hope to pick up another 4 pack before its gone for the season.  Great stuff!
beer_name: Odell Mountain Standard Double Black IPA

review_blob: Thanks for the warnings about the cork.  I opened my bottle in the shower stall just in case and managed not to put an eye out.  This is my first sampling of a "sour ale" and will be my last.  I had to pour it after toughing out a few ounces.  This stuff was nasty.

This is less hoppy and more malty than most IPAs I have tried.   Still, a nice balance.  Pours a pale amber with a quickly settling head.  Finish is on the dry side.  Alcohol well hidden.  Goes down easy.  Nice.
A black IPA.  Wonderful idea!  This combination of an imperial IPA and an imperial Stout works well.  Just be sure to let it warm a bit; at 8 bucks a bomber you want to taste it fully.
beer_name: Stone 15th Anniversary Escondidian Imperial Black IPA

review_blob: This brew has two things going for it.  It is German.  And it is brewed according to their "reinheitsgebot".  In other words, only water, barley and hops are used.  This is a very light bodied beer as pilseners generally are.  I find it a ready accomplice to a good Kentucky bourbon.

This brew pours a hazy light orange color with a quickly dissapating head.  Aroma unremarkable.  However, the taste compensates for that.  This one has a very good balance of hops and malt.  Very tasty and drinkable.  Will buy this one again.
Another Sierra Nevada staple of mine.   Dry, hoppy, tasty and relatively cheap.  What a great brewery!

Fool me once, shame on you.  Fool me twice, shame on me.  I got suckered into paying 9 bucks for what is basically a six pack of Coors.  I didnt see the word Coors on the bottle;  instead they used "AC Golden Brewery".  What a ripoff.
beer_name: AC Golden Colorado Native Amber Lager

review_blob: The deScription says it all.  It does work well for afternoons, evenings and nights as well.

This one rates right up there with the best of American microbrew IPAs.  Might even edge Stone out a little bit.  This brew has an excellent balance of hops and malt and doesnt scrimp on either.  Dont drink it too cold.

From a can as all of Oskar Blues are.  Pours a clear amber with minimal head.  I prefer hoppy beers but this is a little over the top for me.  I wonder what it would taste like to just chew on some hops---maybe something like this.  Its new and I had to give it a try.  Will be buying something else, next time, though.
I dont know why they call this an IPA.  It is more like a Scotch Ale with a bunch of hops added in.  Not a terrible beer, but misnamed.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: 22 oz. bomber from Applejack in Denver.  This tastes more like a stout (reminiscent of Bells Expedition) than an ale.  It is wonderful!  I concur with most of the deScriptive adjectives below and wont repeat them.  The label is a hoot!  Kind of pricey (8 bucks), but worth it.
This is a nice, well balanced  IPA.  Pours gold with moderate carbonation.  Quite dry with little aftertaste.  Priced better than most.

I apparently rated this one under their retired Oatmeal Stout by accident. This is a bad tasting beer with a great presentation.  It is as opaque as 12 mil black plastic sheeting and tastes as if they used some of that sheeting in the brewing process.  I think I will pour the rest of this one... ugh..

Bomber bought in Santa Fe.  Pours a copper hue with quickly diminishing head.  First sips reminded me of prune juice.  This is a rather one dimensional beer with an odd acidic, astringent fruity aftertaste.  Not one of my favorite barleywines.  Probably 15 years ago I tried a Santa Fe Brewery offering called Tree Spirit Stout, which I found amazing.  Too bad its gone.
beer_name: Santa Fe Chicken Killer Barley Wine

review_blob: I agree with a previous post which called this an upgraded Bud.  Barely upgraded.
beer_name: Flying Dog Tire Bite Golden Ale

review_blob: 2008 bomber.  The commercial deScription pegs it.  I wont repeat it.  Good stuff.  The hoppiest barleywine I have tasted.  Will be buying this again.
UPDATED: JAN 23, 2010

Could not find this one in the listings, so I added it.  I called it a Dunkler Bock because the drop down list did not include "Imperial Bock Beer", which this beer claims to be.  It appears that this beer is brewed locally (Highlands Ranch, CO, a suburb of Denver), yet the company seems to be part of some national restaurant/brewpub chain.  Thats all I can tell you about that.  

About the beer:  It pours a dark copper hue with a slight and quickly diminishing head.  The flavor tends toward a German Bock beer, but is a bit on the sweet and syrupy side.  The high alcohol content is obvious.  All in all, not a bad beer.  The price, at $6.99, for a sixer made it worth a try.  Probably wont be trying it again, though.
beer_name: CB & Potts Highlands Ranch Warning Sign Eisbock - 2008

review_blob: This is my favorite Odells brew.  An excellent balance of malt and hops.  Full bodied and rich.  This one would last the voyage across the ocean, unless it was all consumed before they got there.

Stone is consistent.  I have been drinking their IPA for many years and cannot notice any change.  There might be one or two brews out there to offer a challenge, but for the price, this is my staple IPA.  Pour, head, aroma, fllavor, mouthfeel, finish are all top notch.  I sure am glad somebody can make a beer this good, regularly.  Thanks, guys!

If you like an IPA, you will love this.  I hope they have this in heaven (on tap, of course).  It is the hoppiest, tastiest, most full bodied and most complex IPA I have ever consumed.  Packs a punch, too.  Highly recommended.

First time I had seen this at Total in Arvada.  Figured I would check it out as this years Bigfoot wasnt there yet.  It was very good.  
You dont see many beers brewed in Utah, but this one does the state justice.  I now have an alternate to the venerable Bigfoot!

This beer was a disappointment.  With "Bastard" as part of the name, I had my hopes up.  However, this beer was flat.  No head to speak of; no carbonation. Sort of like drinking a beer that you had taken the cap off of yesterday and put it back in the fridge.  Wont be buying this again.

Back in the day before the new American "reinheitsgebot", this beer was among my top favorite German beers.  It still is.  One thing that really amazes me is that this is now actually cheaper than Budweiser!  As the Germans say, "Gut gemacht!".

Whodathunkit?  A great beer in a can.  I like this even better than Oskars canned Old Chub.  It tastes to me like an IPA and ranks up there with the best of them.  A nice value to boot with 12 packs going for 12 bucks around here.

Hmmmm.  Is this an extra special bitter or an early spring beer, or are the two synonymous?  Either way, I found this to be a nice beer.  Pours a hazy amber with quickly settled head.  Nice balance of hops and malt.  Not too thin and not too thick.  Another nice offering from Chico, CA!
Bottle.  Watery, thin, no aftertaste, slightly acidic.  Wont be buying this one again.

This was a strange one.  I didnt detect the "warming blast" of hops mentioned on the label.  It looks like a good beer and pours like one, too.  In the end, though, it tasted more like a lightly carbonated iced tea; astringent and slightly sweet.  Think Ill try something else next time.
Pours a nice dark with quickly diminishing head.  Reminds me immediately of Bells Kalamazoo Stout, only a little more watery.  Coffee and chocolate are there.  A pretty good brew.

Back in the day; before the advent of the microbrew, this was the king of beers; at least on the menu of the blue collar working man.  I used to drink this stuff like water.  Today I discovered that a sixer of tall boys cost 7 bucks as compared to the 4 bucks I paid the last time.  Sorry Bud, your day is done.
